~ THE HOMEWOOD CAMPUS

Thé Johns Hopkins University, founded in 1876, was the
first educational institution in this country oriented toward

graduate study and research — it is often called America’s

1,,..ﬁ.rst,twe.ugi.versiiyr,_.w._4

Today the University comprises six academic divisions:
the Faculty of Arts and Sciences and the Evening College
on the Homewood campus; the School of Medicine, the
School of Hygiene and Public Health, and the School of
Health Services located together with The Johns Hopkins
Hospital in East Baltimore; and the School of Advanced In-
ternational Studies in Washington, D.C. The Applied Phy-
sics Laboratory is operated by the University in Howard
County. ' ‘

Johns Hopkins is the smallest of the nation’s front-rank

- universities; full-time enrollment in all divisions is ap-

proximately 4,500 students.

‘The Arts and Sciences and Evening College divisions

moved in 1916 from downtown Baltimore to Homewood,
the 140-acre North Baltimore estate that had been estab-
lished over a century before by Charles Carroll of Carroll-
ton — a signer of the Declaration of Independence. The
campus was planned as a cohesive unit, with most of the
buildings designed in the stately Georgian style derived

- from historic Homewood House, built in 1801. Consid-

ered one of the most perfect examples of Georgian archi-
tecture in America, the house stands at the main entrance
to the University grounds.

The Faculty of Arts and Sciences, which includes the
undergraduate division, consists of 27 academic depart-
ments offering baccalaureate, master’s, and doctoral pro-
grams in the humanities, natural sciences, physical sci-
ences, engineering, quantitative studies, and social and
behavorial sciences. Some 2,000 undergraduate students

- and 1,000 graduate students are taught by a single faculty

of approximately 300 members.

The oldest of the University’s divisions, the Faculty of Arts
and Sciences has continuously adhered to the philoso-
phy of Daniel Coit Gilman, the first president, who be-
lieved that teaching and research were inseparable con-
stituents of a university, and that the objective of the insti-
tution should be the creation as well as the collection and
dissemination of knowledge.

The Evening College, founded in 1909, is one of the coun-
try’s oldest part-time adult education enterprises and now
serves some 5,500 students. It consists of five divisions:

~arts and the social sciences; engineering, physical, and

mathematical sciences; education; administrative and
business sciences; and special interdisciplinary pro-
grams. In addition to the associate and baccalaureate de-
grees, the Evening College offers programs leading to the
master’'s degree and certificate of advanced study in 15
major areas, including liberal arts, engineering, science,
education, urban planning, and administrative science. A
program leading to the doctorate in education is offered in
human communication and its disorders.

The Milton S. Eisenhower Library

Named after the University’s eighth president, the Eisen-

hower Library houses more than 1.5 million volumes,

which ranks it among the major research libraries in this
country. On the library’s six floors, four of which are
underground, are modern study carrels, an audio depart-
ment, the University Archives, the Dwight D. Eisenhower
Papers Project, and art galleries. The Albert D. Hutzler
Undergraduate Reading Room in Gilman Hall supple-
ments the Eisenhower Library facility.

By Car to Homewood

From the north via Interstate 95 from New York or New Jersey, proceed south on 1-95 until you reach the
Baltimore Beltway (1-695). Take the Beltway west (toward Towson) to Exit 25. Exit, turn left at the stop
sign onto Charles Street. Follow Charles Street south for approximately eight miles to University Park-
way. The University will be ahead of you on your right. Keep in right lane, and enter the curb lane which
begins at the corner of Charles and University. The first traffic light beyond University Parkway will be at
Charles and 34th Streets. The main entrance to the University is on your right.

- EVENTS AT JOHNS HOPKINS |

& Many seminars and lectures organized by the acadefnic

departments are open to the public without charge.

Throughout the year, numerous events are offered by stu-



dent organizations such as the Barnstormers drama

group, the University Band, The Hopkins Glee Club, and
the Student Activities Council. For information about stu-
dent activities call extension 1405.

The Johns Hdpk'ins University Office of Special Events,r lo-

cated in Shriver Hall, presents a variety of cultural, artis-

tic, and educational programs of interest to both the Hop-
kins and Baltimore communities throughout the school
year. Events include concerts (both individual and series),
lectures (both individual and series), recitals, plays, dra-
matic readings, dance performances, other performing
arts events, and all artexhibits in the galleries of the Milton
S. Eisenhower Library. '

~ Most of the programs presented by this office are free.

When tickets are required, they may be purchased by mail
or in person at the Office of Special Events (extension
1451 or 1452), the Book Center in Gilman Hall, or at the
Union Desk. Special student rates are available.

Shriver Hall Concert Series

Each year the Shriver Hall Concert Series, located in
Shriver Hall, presents six concerts of chamber music per-
formed by internationally famous artists. Subscriptions
are available at reasonable prices with special student
rates and may be purchased at the Shriver Hall Concert
Series office (extension 755). Single tickets to each per-
formance may be purchased on the night of the perform-

ance at the box office, if available.

Theatre Hopkins

Theatre Hopkins, an adult community theatre sponsored
by the University with a company of experienced players
and a professional director, presents four productions
each year. Three of these are performed in the Barn, built
in 1803, on what is now the Homewood campus. The final
production is given in the gardens of Evergreen House.
Subscriptions and individual tickets are available at the
Theatre Hopkins office located in Shriver Hall (extension
1095).

Athletics

7~

The modern and complete facilities of the Newton H.

White, Jr. Athletic Center provide a home for intramural
programs and for the University’s twelve intercollegiate
teams in lacrosse, football, soccer, cross-country, bas-

. ketball, wrestling, swimming, fencing, baseball, track,

tennis and golf. For information on admission to athletic
events, call extension 791.





- EVERGREEN HOUSE

The Evergreeh House, located at 4545 North Charles

Street, was bequeathed to the University by John Work

Garrett in 1942. It is maintained by the Evergreen House
~ Foundation as a research library for the benefitoftheUni-
versity and the people of Baltimore.

The house, a classical revival structure, is situated on
twenty-six beautifully wooded acres, with a formal garden
leading from the great rare book library at the rear of the
house. In addition to rare books, the Evergreen House in-

cludes among its possessions rare coin and stamp collec-

tions, Tiffany glass, and the Alice Garrett collection of
modern paintings, drawings and sculpture of Dufy, Bon-

nard, Derain, Picasso, Vuillard, Bakst, Sterne, Forain, and

Zuloaga.

The 'Libraﬂry, a rich resource of natural history and Ameri-
can and Maryland imprints and incunabula, is open from

2:00 to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. Arrangements
can be made for those desiring to do research or forgroup

tours of the mansion by calling 435-3376.

THE HOMEWOOD COMMUNITY

The Homewood campus is in the center of an interesting
and diverse community. Within walking distance are sev-

~eral community business districts, gracious gardens and

parks, numerous churches, three hospitals, the Baltimore
Museum of Art, and a branch of the City’s public library.

Baltimore is a city of neighborhoods, and those adjacent
to the campus include Hampden, on the west, one of the
villages which grew around cotton mills and factories that,
in the 1880’s, provided about four-fifths of the sail canvas

‘used around the world. Guilford, to the northeast, is a

planned community of elegant single family residences
built in neo-Georgian architecture, some dating back to
1920. Charles Village, to the southeast, was named in 1968
by a group of neighborhood boosters who wanted to give a
sense of community to “Peabody Heights.” The Charles
Village area is the neighborhood with the highest popula-

tion of students and young professionals.

These neighborhoods and others, i.e., Harwood, Reming-
ton, Roland Park, Oakenshaw, Tuscany-Canterbury and
Wyman Park, comprise the Greater Homewood commu-
nity and are served by an umbrella or advocacy corpora-
tion which the University convened and continues to

support.

Places to Eat

In the Homewood community, there are many places to
eat ranging from take-out sandwich shops to gourmet res-
taurants. On campus, the cafeteria in the Hopkins Union
and the snack bar in the dormitories are open to the public.

A cafe, open weekdays except Monday, is located on the

ground floor of the Baltimore Museum of Art.
The Baltimore Museum of Art

The Baltimore Museum of Art, located on the southern
edge of the Homewood campus on land donated to the
city by the University, is highly regarded in the art world
for its famous Cone Collection of nineteenth and early
twentieth century paintings, many by Matisse and
Picasso. On display continuously are works by the old
masters, sculpture, contemporary art and fine period fur-
niture. The Museum is open daily except Monday.

are in session; they depart from the Admissions Office in
Garland Hall at 11:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m.

Dr. Ira Remsen, first professor of:éhér'r’iigtﬁr‘y and second

president of the University, discovered saccharin in 1879;
he also created the American Chemical Journal.

Dr. William Foxwell Albright, the “verifier of the Old Tes-
tament,” determined the authenticity of the Dead Sea

~Scrollsin 1948.

Dr. Henry A. Rowland, first professor of physics, invented
the concave grating.

A lecturer at Hopkins in 1877, Charles Peirce became
known as the “Father of Semiotics” and together with
William James, was known also as the “Father of Prag-
matism.”

The carbon monoxide eliminator, an oxidizing device to
reduce the danger of auto exhaust fumes, was developed
by Dr. Joseph Frazier.

Woodrow Wilson, the first and only U.S. President with an
earned Ph.D., earned his doctorate in 1886 at Hopkins.

Dr. James Sylvester, the first professor of mathematics,
developed the invariant theory of matter and founded the
American Journal of Mathematics.

The modern concepts of research in cell and develop-
mental biology were established by Dr. Benjamin Willier.

Hopkins firsts in psychology include: the first psycho-
logical lab in the nation founded at Hopkins in 1883 by G.
Stanley Hall; the first American Ph.D. in psychology
granted to Joseph Jastrow in 1886; Dr. John B. Watson’s
work in behaviorism.

Dr. Walter Patrick in the 1920’s discovered the amazing
properties of silica gel and invented an inexpensive and
simple method of producing the substance in quantity.

Dr. William McElroy began studies in 1948 which un-

locked the secrets of luciferin and luciferase, compounds
responsible for biological luminescence as exemplified by
the firefly.

Dr. George Huntington Williams developed a revolution-
ary technique of rock sectioning and a microscope that
could analyze these thin slices.

Dr. Leo Spitzer, internationally known philologist, and Dr.
Georges Poulet, critic of French literature, led the Revo-

~ lution in Literary Criticism.

The country’s firstR.O.T.C. was established at Johns Hop-
kinsin 1916.

The phenomenon of resonance radiation, which became a
major technique of 20th century physics, was discovered
by Dr. Robert W. Wood.

Sidney Lanier became the first university poet-in-resi-
dence in 1879.

The Writing Seminars, the first graduate program of its
kind, were established by poet Elliott Coleman.
